uk.ac.ebi.utils.threading

Class BatchProcessor<S,D>

  • java.lang.Object
    • uk.ac.ebi.utils.threading.BatchProcessor<S,D>
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    SizeBasedBatchProcessor

    public abstract class BatchProcessor<S,D>
extends Object

    A simple class to manage processing of data in multi-thread mode.

    The idea implemented here is that process(Object, Object...) runs a loop where:

    • gets a data item from its input source of type S
    • optionally transforms the data item and sends the result to the current destination of type D
    • invokes handleNewTask(Object, boolean), which decides if it's time to issue a new processing thread. The latter possibly create a new destination object, via getDestinationSupplier() and hence the caller should assign the current destination to it.

    Each new invocation performed by handleNewTask(Object, boolean) consists of the creation of a new task which is submitted an executor service and hence the processing can happen in multi-thread mode.

    process(Object, Object...) should invoke waitExecutor(String) after the loop above, to make the parallel task executions complete.

    This also resets the internal ExecutorService, which will be recreated (once) upon the first invocation of getExecutor(). This behaviour ensures that process(Object) can be invoked multiple times reusing the same processor instance (normally that’s not possible for an ExecutorService which of method ExecutorService.awaitTermination(long, TimeUnit) was called).

    You can find a usage example of this class in the rdf-utils-jena package.

    Author:
    brandizi
    Date:
    1 Dec 2017

        protected D handleNewTask(D currentDest)

      • handleNewTask

        protected D handleNewTask(D currentDest,
                          boolean forceFlush)

        This is the method that possibly issues a new task, via the getExecutor(), which runs the consumer against the current destination.

        Parameters:
        forceFlush - if true it flushes the data independently of #getChunkSize().

      • decideNewTask

        protected abstract boolean decideNewTask(D dest)

        handleNewTask(Object, boolean) decides to generate a new task based on the value returned by this.

      • getDestinationSupplier

        public Supplier<D> getDestinationSupplier()

        Every time that handleNewTask(Object, boolean) decides it’s time to work on a new task and destination D, this supplier is used to generate such new destination.

      • setDestinationSupplier

        public BatchProcessor<S,D> setDestinationSupplier(Supplier<D> destinationSupplier)

      • getExecutorFactory

        public Supplier<ExecutorService> getExecutorFactory()

        The factory for the thread pool manager used by process(Object, Object...).

        By default this is HackedBlockingQueue.createExecutor(). Normally you shouldn't need to change this parameter, unless you want some particular execution policy.

      • setExecutorFactory

        public void setExecutorFactory(Supplier<ExecutorService> executorFactory)

      • getExecutor

        public ExecutorService getExecutor()

        This is initialised using the first time you call it, by means of getExecutorFactory(). If you invoke waitExecutor(String), in process(Object, Object...), as recommended, the internal ExecutorService returned by this is made to null again and then re-initialised by this method upon its next call.

      • waitExecutor

        protected void waitExecutor(String pleaseWaitMessage)

        Waits that all the parallel jobs submitted to the processor are finished. It keeps polling ExecutorService.isTerminated() and invoking ExecutorService.awaitTermination(long, TimeUnit).

        As explained above, this resets the ExecutorService that is returned by getExecutor(), so that the next time that method is invoked, it will get a new executor from getExecutorFactory().

        Parameters:
        pleaseWaitMessage - the message to be reported (via logger/INFO level) while waiting.

      • wrapTask

        protected Runnable wrapTask(Runnable task)

        Wraps the task into some common operations. At the moment,

        • wraps exception,
        • logs the progress of completed tasks every taskLogPeriod completed tasks.
